title: Yes, South Africa’s clean energy output up from zero to ‘over 4.5%’ since 2010
subtitle: The South African government is making headway in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, with clean energy’s share of the country’s power mix on the rise. It’s grown from zero to over 8% since 2010.
author: africacheck.org
vclaim:
• None At a recent wind energy conference in Cape Town, South Africa, energy minister Gwede Mantashe said South Africa’s clean energy had grown to over 4.5% within five years.
• None The increase of clean energy’s contribution from 0% to 4.5% happened between 2013 and 2015.
• None In 2019, renewable energy made up more than 8% of South Africa’s energy mix.

Conclusion: Clean energy’s share of South Africa’s power mix rose from 0% in 2010 to 4.5% in 2015.

Gwede Mantashe, South Africa’s energy minister, recently said the government had successfully increased the contribution of clean energy from 0% in 2010 to over 4.5% within five years.

This is supported by data from the Independent Power Producer Projects office and experts in the field. But much of the increase actually took place between 2013 and 2015. In 2019, the figure stood at 8.3%.
